data.title: Selection expansion command and hotkey
data.body:
One of the features I can't live without is selection expansion and contraction. This is obviously language specific but it would be amazing.

Here are two implementations:
- https://www.jetbrains.com/resharper/help/Coding_Assistance__Extend_Shrink_Selection.html
- https://github.com/aronwoost/sublime-expand-region

data.title: Color Theme completely changed
data.body: I used to edit my TSQL scripts on Visual Studio Code. When was added the feature to support Themes, the Dark themes was completely changed (at least for TSQL scripts). Ok, I started using the Monokai Dimmed, and now, on the last version, it was completely changed again. Why do this on existing themes??? Would be easier just create another theme ? :(

data.title: Markdown Preview does not interpret kbstyle() [Not sure if it is a Bug]
data.body:
In the vscode-docs repo there are some markdown documents who contains function like syntax "kbstyle()"

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2528972/11336344/acd245ec-91cb-11e5-90c8-c53b931cef89.png)

The Markdown preview doesn't seem to understand this syntax, but in the official documentation page it has a different coloring.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2528972/11336368/e6c8bb0a-91cb-11e5-9886-b71956591429.png)

I'm not sure if this is a Bug, or just an expected behavior, as I haven't found any documentation on this "kbstyle()" syntax

data.title: [bat] Batch File Syntax highlighting not working on variables or comments.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
After upgrading to version 0.10.1 Syntax highlighting within windows .bat files has become reduced.

Previous versions would syntax highlight variables (%VARIABLENAME%) and comments(REM-COMMENT TEXT" now these both appear as normal text:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/594681/11335412/f2e5a0c6-91d3-11e5-84d7-51d17cc69b0c.png)

data.title: Source map debugging not working for built in extensions

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Steps to reproduce:
- clone vscode and follow steps here https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#build-and-run-from-source
- run scripts\code
- open VSCode on the vscode folder
- select Attach to Extension Host launch config
- Attach debugger
- open bufferSyncSupport.ts and set a breakpoint on line 62
- open a ts file in the instance started via scripts\code and type into the file

Observe: debugger not hit.

If you set a breakpoint in the JS file everything works as expected.

data.title: [debug] Support to add launch configs after the fact
data.body:
I would like to add an additional config to an existing launch.json.
Typically this config if from the same debug type as the existing configs, but has a variation in one or more arguments.
Intellisense on the configurations array level could offer to insert configs.

data.title: git.path in user settings
data.body:
I have portable git on my Windows 10. In VS Code you can set user settings for this section:

```
    //-------- Git configuration --------

    // Is git enabled
    "git.enabled": true,

    // Path to the git executable
    "git.path": null,

    // Whether auto fetching is enabled.
    "git.autofetch": true,
```

So I set "git.path": "c:\tools\git\bin" and restart, it still can't find git install.

Later I set System Env Path to include git, then it's happy; seems setting above doesn't really change anything?

Best,

Dong

data.title: No autocompletion from .d.ts files inside node_modules for JavaScript projects

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Autocompletion from .d.ts definition files placed in node_modules directory works just fine for TypeScript projects (projects which have a .tsconfig file).
It even works for JS-based projects if one has .d.ts files inside the project. However if the definition files are placed inside node_modules directory in a JS-based project VS Code doesn't seem to pick them up.

data.title: Add Edge to list of browsers
data.body:
…so it can be used to add browser support info in CSS IntelliSense.

Fixes #280

data.title: Fix function keyword syntax
data.body:
This fixes a longstanding bug highlighting code like:

``` posh
# This is ok
Test-Highlight -Something StringValue
# This is not
Test-Highlight -TestFunction StringValue
# and it breaks this:
Test-Highlight -Something StringValue
```

I also fixed scope on function names, like:

``` posh
function Test-Thing { Get-Command $VariableName }
# the function name should be highlighted as above, and both "global"s should be the same...
function global:Test-Thing { Get-Command $global:VariableName }
Function LOCAL:Test-Thing { Get-Command $local:VariableName }
FUNCTION script:Test-Thing { Get-Command $script:VariableName }
```

Same change as https://github.com/SublimeText/PowerShell/pull/137

data.title: VSCode/OmniSharp looking for DNX runtime in wrong directory
data.body:
On Mac OS, DNVM installed the DNX runtime in `/usr/local/lib/dnx/runtimes/dnx-mono.1.0.0-rc1-final`. However, OmniSharp in Visual Studio Code was incorrectly looking in `/Users/danlo/.dnx/runtimes`. To get it to work properly, I created a symbolic link:

```
ln -s /usr/local/lib/dnx/runtimes /Users/danlo/.dnx/runtimes
```

This smells super hacky though.

data.title: "dnu restore" tries to use ASP.NET beta3?
data.body:
I've got ASP.NET 5 RC 1 installed, but the "dnu restore" command in Visual Studio code is explicitly trying to use beta3:

```
cd '/Users/danlo/src/aspnettest/TestApp1' ; /Users/danlo/.k/runtimes/kre-mono.1.0.0-beta3/bin/dnu restore
danlo-mbp1:~ danlo$ cd '/Users/danlo/src/aspnettest/TestApp1' ; /Users/danlo/.k/runtimes/kre-mono.1.0.0-beta3/bin/dnu restore
-bash: /Users/danlo/.k/runtimes/kre-mono.1.0.0-beta3/bin/dnu: No such file or directory
```

If I run "dnu restore" myself, it works fine. 

How do I fix Visual Studio code?
